comment.author: 98811519@N00
comment._content: Does anyone know what that little cloth sign in everyone's window means? The one with the blue star surrounded by the red border? I think my mom told me a long time ago that it meant you could go to that house if you were lost or in trouble or something, but people don't have them anymore :(

comment.author: 22924230@N03
comment._content:
I'm rushed with a feeling of "home" when I look at this photo....though I was born many years later and never lived in D.C.  I have to keep coming back to take a peek into the past.
I'm curious about the narrow pocket between the doors...is that a passage to the back of the building?

comment.author: 7979645@N03
comment._content: I think the cloth sign in the window indicates that a member of the family is in the service.

comment.author: 52992460@N00
comment._content: The Blue Star Mothers of America was founded in 1942 The first meeting was held in February It was for mothers who had children in the war.. They still exist. www.bluestarmothers.org/history.php

comment.author: 23224989@N07
comment._content:
Title:  But Granny, Superman already whipped Hitler!
OR
Birthday Without Daddy

comment.author: 23393335@N06
comment._content: There were some different signs. I think one was for a son in the service and another was for a service death.

comment.author: 24025018@N06
comment._content: I believe the Blue Star indicated a service member and a Gold Star indicated death of a service member

comment.author: 12104215@N03
comment._content: those banisters are a bit much for lower middle class homes.

comment.author: 11865422@N08
comment._content: this looks a lot like frederick, md to me. they had those little pocket doorways sometimes between their row houses... downtown frederick has been kept as a historic district, so a lot of these pics that are marked as dc look like frederick looks like now still... maybe this was all a demolished part of dc.
